captions.text:
Prepare for the 50th anniversary of the Bond
franchise
with a new film by the director

whose most famous action scene to-date was
this.

Skyfall: the overrated movie that thrilled
audiences worldwide -

only because it was way better than Quantum
of Solace.

Suit up with 007, the super secret MI-6 agent
who everyone knows by his real name.

In an opening so action-packed, you'll forget
to ask yourself:

Why didn't the conductor stop this train when
it's entire back carriage was ripped off?
And why aren't these people scared?

When Bond is abruptly killed, it'll only take
the link of one Adele song

before he anticlimactically pops up in the
most secluded corner of the globe
that conveniently has CNN in English.

But when Bond returns to the high-stakes world
of espionage, he's faced with:

"The prime minister's ordered an inquiry.
You'll have to appear."

Meet Raoul Silva, the Bond villian we've been
waiting for

... because he doesn't show up until half
way through the movie.

An antagonist with a plan so complex, he
wants to get caught but makes it nearly impossible

knows months ahead of time the exact place
to plant explosives during a chase he didn't
even know was going to happen,

Discover the latest in super-secret gadgetry
like

and a tracking device larger than the one
Bond used in the 60's.

"Here's a nice little transmitting device.
It's fitted into the heel of your shoe."

Bond will use these tools to hunt down a terrorist
who stole a list of secret agents.

"The computer drive containing the identity
of almost every NATO agent."

... which the writers stole from the plot
of Mission Impossible.

A film with action so artsy, you'll strain
to watch fight scenes shot in total darkness.

An ending so goofy, they just ripped it off
from Home Alone.

And a hero so sexually aggressive, you'll
wonder:

isn't he sort of raping that former child
prostitute?

Wait, whatever happened to that hard drive
they were looking for?
Wasn't that the whole point of the movie?
Make sure to subscribe for more Honest Trailers,

and check out last week's episode where we
get some witches b*tchin' about the new action
I sunk your battle ship, b*tch.
Your belly button taste like broccoli... yummy.

comments.author: Hénry Bruyére

comments.text:
Can someone concisely explain to me why this film is considered to be 
great? Particularly what exactly I'm supposed to be impressed with apart 
form the gorgeous cinematography from Roger Deakins?

Because all I saw were inconsistencies, a contrived ending, plot 
conveniences and blatant character choices that made no sense for example:

Why would Bond take M to a secluded place with almost no weapons or 
security to protect M? That's a horrible idea.

Also how did Bond survive the shot? See I'm fine with a spy movie taking 
such liberties but the fans of this movie take pride in the fact that it's 
STEEPED in realism which doesn't make any sense to me as this movie wasn't 
realistic in the slightest. From Bond surviving to Silva's plan.

Why is it considered to be such a great movie in the franchise when we 
classics such as From Russia With Love, Goldfinger, OHMSS, and Casino 
Royale?

I'm just looking for a good discussion here and someone to explain to me 
why they loved this film. I've tried really hard to like but I just don't 
seem to be able to. Also the Bournification of Bond  really annoys me. He's 
so sad and gloomy all the time. You're JAMES BOND FFS. Enjoy yourself.

So on you go! please keep it civil.﻿

comments.author: Eric Schaertl

comments.text:
As a Bond fan I am enjoying the films and I don't hate Craig himself but 
this is not really the Bond that Ian Fleming wrote about, I think the film 
makers have confused source material with gritty. Apparently Fleming didn't 
approve of Connery at first because he was a former body builder and had 
too many biceps and I have to wonder were he alive today if he'd approve of 
Craig because the same applies. Bond isn't a meat cake. The joke about 
Jason Bourne is pretty spot on. They're treating Bond as if he's a stone 
cold government thug and while Bond was emotionally remote to a certain 
degree he still had a refined nature to him that Craig as an actor 
lacks. Brosnan had it closer to the book Bond than Craig does.﻿
